comment: Version 1.0: our test module for the RE Cares Hackathon
displayText: This module discusses passwords: how to pick strong passwords, how to remember them, and how to get taken advantage of.

content.title: Getting Started
content.mainText:
Passwords have stood the test of time as one of the main tools of authentication for user accounts.

But user password practices remain as the least secure element in this system.

In this module we discuss good and bad practices for creating passwords, and various management options that enable you to maintain strong passwords for all your accounts.

content.title: Password Reuse
content.question: When you create a new password for a new account, do you use a password that you already know?
content.tooltip:
Always

means you are using the same password (or a small number of passwords) for all/almost all of your on-line accounts

Usually

means that you typically reuse your passwords when creating a new account

Sometimes means that you reuse passwords fairly infrequently, and tend to come up with new passwords most of the time

Never means that every time you create a new on-line account, you come up with a new password

checklist.itemName: Update passwords on current accounts so that they are unique

answers.postText: If a hacker manages to get your username and password for one account, they can use that information to also access other accounts.  It is a good idea never to use the same password in different accounts.

checklist.itemName: Update passwords on current accounts so that they are unique

answers.postText: If a hacker manages to get your username and password for one account, they can use that information to also access other accounts.  It is a good idea never to use the same password in different accounts.

content.title: Picking a password
content.question: When you pick a new password, what sorts of passwords do you pick? Please, select all answers that apply.
content.tooltip: You can select multiple answers. When you selected all the answers that apply, click the 'Done' button.

checklist.itemName: Update your password(s) to be more complex, following best practices discussed in this module
Update your password(s) to be more complex, following best practices discussed in this module

answers.answerText: Acronyms of song lyrics or titles (e.g., AIWALY is And I Will Always Love You)

content.postText: If we use passwords that are short, contain real words, or have no numbers or special characters, they are often easy to guess or easy to find via brute force (trying over and over). Passwords which are acronyms are harder to guess, but passwords that are long and randomly generated are very hard to guess or to discover.

content.title: Changing the Password
content.question: How often do you change your passwords
content.tooltip:
Never - once you create an account, you never change your password for it.

Sometimes - you change some of the passwords for your accounts every couple of years, but you might not be doing it consistently.

Always - you change passwords once a year or more frequently for all or most of your accounts

checklist.itemName: Update all passwords which havent't been updated in 1+ years
Update passwords on current accounts so that they are unique

content.postText:
Changing passwords and having passwords that expire make it more difficult for hackers to get your password. How often you have to change depends on how important the account is and how complicated your original password is. If you have a strong password, you can change it less often. Sites which are very popular (e.g., Gmail, Facebook, etc.) are more likely to get hacked, and should have more frequently changing passwords.

But how do I know when a password has expired? Answer coming soon...

content.title: Personal and Business email accounts
content.mainText: Now, let's talk about the use of email addresses when creating on-line accounts
content.question: Which of these three people is most like you?
content.tooltip: Please take a look at each story. Select the one that seems the most like you, even if there are some differences between the person's story, and your own personal practices.

stories.storyText: I've had one email address for a long time, and I do everything using it. So, when I create a new account - whether for business or for my own personal use, I always use the same email.

checklist.itemName: add a separate email address for work/personal use

stories.storyText: I have a personal email address for a long time and I have been using it for many different accounts. I also do have my business address and sometimes I use it to create new accounts, but my old accounts, whether business or personal are all under my personal email address.

I have a business email that is separate from my personal email address. I always separate accounts I need for business and for personal use. I always use my business email for business/work accounts (my accounting software, my business's social networking pages, and so on). I always use my personal email for my personal accounts on different web sites.

content.postText: It is a good practice to have separate work and personal email addresses.  If a hacker manages to get one address and a password they can only access the sites which use that email, and not others.   Having separate email addresses reducing the damage and spread of hacking your accounts.

content.title: Password Strength
content.mainText:
Password strength is determined by how difficult it is for an automated tool to guess your password.

Some types of passwords are much easier for password-cracking programs to guess. Examples of such weak passwords include:

  • English words (or words in another popular language, such as French, German, Spanish)
    • examples: cat, burrito, Vacation
  • simple numeric combinations:
    • examples: 123456, 10001
  • combinations of characters and numbers that follow alphabetical order of keyboard layout:
    • examples: abc123, qwerty, asdf1234, xyz0987

Strong passwords are combinations of letters, numbers, and special characters that are difficult for password cracking programs to guess. Some ways to recognize a strong password are:

  • the longer the password, the stronger it typically is
  • passwords that mix letters, numbers and special characters are typically stronger than passwords that only use letters
  • short passwords that do not include vocabulary words are typically stronger than passwords of similar length that do.

content.title: Good Practices
content.mainText: There are some good practices that one can follow in order to create strong, hard-to-steal passwords, and in order to prevent password theft.
content.extraText: Select one of the following below

content.title: Good practices for selecting passwords
content.mainText:
Here are some rules of thumb for selecting individual passwords and for maintaining multiple passwords across all your on-line accounts.

  • Limit password reuse: try using a different password for all your accounts. At the very least, use different passwords for your major, commonly-used accounts.
  • Suggestions for strong passwords:
    • A password that consists of 12 or more randomly selected characters is a strong password. Such passwords though are hard to remember.
    • A good proxy can be a password that is derived from your favorite song lyric, poetry stanza, or book quote. Let us use the following lines from Lewis Carrol's Jabberwocky: He took his vorpal sword in hand; Long time the manxome foe he sought.
      We the first letter of each word to form the the first version of the password: 'HthvsihLttmfhs. This is a 14-letter combination, so this password is already strong. We can make it more memorable and stronger at the same time by adding a couple of numbers and some punctuation: H1thvsih-L2ttmfhs!
    • 4-5 randomly selected words linked by numbers or special characters. Let's take addition, human, guard, spark, and violet.We can form a password AdditionHumanGuardSparkViolet. It is a long password (29 characters), but it only requires you to remember five words.
      This password can be additionally strengthened by adding numbers and special characters: Addition$Human1Guard#Spark7Violet.
    • Easy-to-remember passphrase. For example: IDecidedThatILikeStrawberryIceCream. Caveat: these should be changed often - 2-3 times a year.
